description.summary: Greek mythological creatures depicted as bird-women with woman's head and torso combined with bird wings, talons, and lower body. Originally wind spirits who evolved from beautiful to grotesque in mythology, known for snatching food and people.
description.full: Harpies are creatures from Greek mythology portrayed as having a woman's head and torso with the wings, talons, and lower body of a bird. Originally conceived as wind spirits and daughters of Thaumas and Electra, they evolved from beautiful winged maidens to grotesque monsters in later mythology. Known as 'the snatchers,' harpies were said to snatch away food, carry off people, and torment victims, most famously the blind prophet Phineus whom they plagued by fouling his food until freed by the Argonauts. The three most famous harpies are Aello (storm swift), Ocypete (swift wing), and Celaeno (dark). They possessed incredible flight speed and the ability to carry away people or objects. Harpies came to symbolize divine punishment, guilt, and sudden disappearance. The term 'harpy' has evolved in modern usage to mean a shrewish or nagging woman, representing a negative linguistic evolution.

etymology.origin: From Greek 'harpyia,' from 'harpazein' meaning 'to snatch' or 'to seize'
etymology.meaning: The snatchers or the swift robbers

related_phenomena.name: Siren
related_phenomena.description: Also bird-women in original Greek, but singers rather than snatchers

related_phenomena.name: Sphinx
related_phenomena.description: Another Greek hybrid creature with woman's head

physical.later_evolution: Grotesque bird-women with foul appearance and smell

features.description: Human upper body, face of a woman
Feathered lower body and legs of a bird
Often depicted with pale or sickly appearance

physical.morphology: Hybrid creature combining human upper body with avian lower body, wings, and talons. Evolution from beautiful to hideous over course of mythology.

abilities.description: Swift as the wind, extremely fast fliers
Carry away people to unknown locations
Contaminate and befoul food and surroundings

behavior.role: Agents of divine punishment, snatchers, tormentors
patterns: Snatch food before it can be eaten
Foul remaining food with stench and excrement
Serve as instruments of divine vengeance

origins.cultural_roots: Greek mythology, originally wind spirits (daughters of sea god Thaumas and Oceanid Electra)
origins.evolution: Transformed from beautiful swift wind spirits to foul grotesque monsters in later mythology

timeline.significance: Early mention of harpies as daughters of Thaumas and Electra
Famous account of Phineus and the harpies
Harpies appear as prophecy-givers and tormentors

famous_harpies.name: Celaeno
famous_harpies.role: One of the primary harpies; gives prophecy in Aeneid

famous_harpies.name: Podarge
famous_harpies.role: Sometimes listed as fourth harpy; mother of Achilles' horses

phineus_myth.description: Blind prophet Phineus was tormented by harpies who would snatch or foul his food whenever he tried to eat, leaving him starving
phineus_myth.resolution: The Argonauts (specifically the Boreads - Zetes and Calais, winged sons of the North Wind) chased the harpies away
phineus_myth.outcome: Harpies fled to the Strophades islands and promised never to torment Phineus again
phineus_myth.significance: Demonstrates harpies as instruments of divine punishment for Phineus's transgression

genealogy.siblings: Iris (goddess of rainbow and divine messenger)
genealogy.offspring: Podarge was said to be mother of Achilles's immortal horses Balius and Xanthus (by Zephyrus)

textual.name: Argonautica
textual.author: Apollonius of Rhodes
textual.description: Account of Phineus and the harpies

symbolic_interpretations.name: Divine punishment
symbolic_interpretations.description: Harpies represent divine vengeance and punishment for transgression

symbolic_interpretations.name: Guilt personification
symbolic_interpretations.description: Represent guilty conscience and psychological torment

symbolic_interpretations.name: Sudden disappearance
symbolic_interpretations.description: Explain mysterious disappearances of people or objects

symbolic_interpretations.name: Storm spirits
symbolic_interpretations.description: Originally represented destructive winds and storms

literature: Dante's Inferno (suicides transformed into trees tormented by harpies)
film_tv: Various fantasy films and TV series
heraldry: Harpy Monument (Tomb of the Harpies, Xanthos)

linguistic_legacy.modern_usage: The term 'harpy' has acquired negative connotations in English, referring to a shrewish, nagging, or predatory woman
linguistic_legacy.note: This represents linguistic evolution from mythological creature to gendered insult
